newsitem.title: UK: PRESS DIGEST - Evening Standard - April 21.
newsitem.headline: PRESS DIGEST - Evening Standard - April 21.

text.p: Prepared for Reuters by The Broadcast Monitoring Company
IRA ALERTS SHUT KEY LONDON STATIONS

Today nearly 400,000 early morning commuters were affected as the IRA gave coded messages to police during rush hour. London travel was thrown into chaos as most major railway stations and Heathrow airport were closed and evacuated.

The way in which Littlewoods and its adviser BZW are going about selling its chain of stores is coming under attack from high street store Boots. Boots is set to start negotiations with other groups it believes to be interested in buying parts of the business. Chief executive Sir James Blyth is frustrated by the bidding process, feeling that no one wants to buy the whole chain, but that several parties would be interested in a few shops.
GAS PLAN FOR PRICE CUTS RECEIVES A BOOST

Despite an outcry from rival gas suppliers and worries voiced by the Gas Consumers Council, plans by British Gas to cut prices in areas of domestic competition have received a boost. Industry watchdog Ofgas investigation into cuts was backed by more than half of respondents.
MARKETS WOBBLE ON TALK OF FRENCH POLL

Investors in overnight markets were unnerved with the idea that French President Jacques Chirac may dissolve the National Assembly and announce a General Election. Traders have suggested that the move anticipated a new bout of uncertainty over EMU.
P&O AND SERCO TEAM ENLISTS WITH OZ NAVY

In what is the second recent British success in a major defence contract an outsourcing contract has been won with the Royal Australian Navy in a joint venture between P&O and diversified task management company Serco Group. The contract is for 10 years and is worth A300 Australian dollars (142 million stg).
